bibl.title: Letter from Leonard Wood to William Ludlow, November 3, 1900

div1.p: Wood states that he never accused Ludlow of concealing information, but that newspapers have misconstrued his statements, through false deductions and inferences. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to William Ludlow, November 3, 1900
div1.opener:
Copy
November 3, 1900
Brigadier General William Ludlow, U. S. Army.
War College Board.
1744 G Street. Washington. D. C.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
Your letter of October 27th. was delivered to me en route
to St. Augustin together with other mail which arrived just prior to
my departure.

It was my intention to make my letter of October 25th. explicit,
both in justice to you and to myself.

I stated to a number of newspaper correspondents, who called
upon me while I was at the War Department, that I had said nothing
which warranted the inference that yellow fever had been concealed
in Havana, but I told them that formerly it had not been published
in full day by day as at present. Col. Black was present at this in-
terview. The correctness of this statement was confirmed by you in
our interview at the Metropolitan Club, when you informed me that you
had published a statement monthly. This whole matter seems to have
grown out of the deductions and inferences made by a newspaper re-
presentative. There is no statement of the kind attributed to me, but
the newspaper correspondent infers that ........&c. &c.

I am sure that your own experience with newspapers has been
such that you appreciate fully the impossibility of guarding against
deductions and conclusions being made which are entirely contrary to
the spirit and intention of the interview.

In conclusion: I have made no statement which warranted anyone
saying that you, or Genl Brooke or anyone connected with you, concealed the presence
of yellow fever in Havana. Such an inference is absolutely unwarran-
ted. This was stated to the representatives of the press at the in-
terview above referred to.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Leonard Wood Official copy respectfully furnished the Adjutant General. U.S. Army.
